questions.text: A male presented with discharge as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pilonidal sinus The given image shows the pilonidal sinus.

Highyeild:

Pilonidal sinus is a condition found in natal cleft overlying coccyx, consisting of one or more, usually non infected midline openings, which communicate with a fibrous tract lined by granulation tissue and contain hair lying loosely in lumen. Clinical features More frequently seen in men, before fourth decade of life Intermittent pain, swelling and discharge at base of spine History of repeated abscess that have burst spontaneously or incised away from midline Conservative management: Simple cleaning of tracks and removal of all hair and strict hygiene for those with minimal symptoms In case of acute exacerbation ( abscess) - drained through small longitudinal incision made over abscess and off midline with curettage of granulation tissue and hair In chronic cases, surgery is done Laying open all tracks with or without marsupialisation Excision of all tracks with or without primary closure Excision of all tracks with closure by some other means such as Limberg flap, Z plasty

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Anal fistula - patient usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain(which increased until temporary relief occurs when pus discharges). An opening is seen around anal verge Option: B. Painful defecation, bleeding per rectum, constipation and longitudinal tear in distal anal canal are suggestive of anal fissure. Option: C. External hemorrhoids are located distal to dentate line and are covered with anoderm. It presents as sudden onset, olive shaped , painful blue subcutaneous swelling at anal margin and if the patient presents within first 48 hours, the clot may be evacuated under local anesthesia

questions.text: A man presented to the emergency department after RTA with complaints of chest pain and breathing difficulty. An X- ray was done and is given below. What type of breathing pattern is observed in this patient? RTA - Road Traffic Accident
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paradoxical The patient has flail chest (Four consecutive displaced rib fractures of the mid right thoracic cavity), paradoxical respiration is seen

Highyeild:

Flail chest results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures ( defined as three or more ribs fractured in two or more places) Diagnosis made clinically in patients who are not ventilated. For confirmation , paradoxical motion of chest wall segment can be observed On inspiration , loose segment of chest wall is moved inwards and therefore less air moves into lungs On expiration , segment moves outwards ( paradoxical respiration ) There is high risk of developing pneumothorax or hemothorax and CT remains gold standard for diagnosis Treatment : Oxygen administration , analgesia and physiotherapy If chest tube in palace , topical intrapleural local analgesia via tube can be used Ventilation: reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite analgesia and oxygen therapy Internal fixation of ribs : useful in patients with isolated or severe chest injury and pulmonary contusion

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Cheyne-Stokes respiration - periodic breathing that occurs in deep sleep in normal persons and is more common in congestive cardiac failure, uremia, premature infants, unacclimatized persons at high altitude. Option: C. Biot’s respiration is a type of abnormal breathing in which 3 to 4 cycles of normal respiration is followed by abrupt onset of apnea. Before apnea , deep gasps occur. It is seen in meningitis, a disease affecting medulla of the brain, increased intracranial pressure, Morphine poisoning. Option: D. Kussmaul breathing is seen in diabetic ketoacidosis ( rapid and deep respiration or “air hunger”), occurs due to accumulation of metabolic acids such as acetoacetic acid and beta hydroxy butyric acid producing metabolic acidosis and stimulating respiratory centers

questions.text: A mother brought her 3-month-old male child to the hospital, who is currently unable to pass urine. A similar issue was reported 15 days ago. The catheter could be passed without difficulty. The image of the micturating cystourethrogram is given below. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Destruction of valves Micturating cystourethrogram reveals marked dilatation of the prostatic portion of the urethra consistent with posterior urethral valves and the most appropriate management is destruction of valves

Highyeild:

Posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small slit within them posteriorly and they lie just dorsal to the verumontanum and cause obstruction to urethra Though they are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow , catheters can be passed retrogradely without any difficulty. They must be detected and treated early to minimize degree of renal failure Diagnosis: Antenatal ultrasound shows distended bladder , dilated prostatic urethra and hydroureteronephrosis More the obstruction, more earlier the presentation Presentation in adolescence is rare Investigations: Ultrasound: assess impaired renal function , checks renal cortical thickness Voiding cystourethrogram: dilated posterior urethra. Nuclear renography: checks differential renal function Bladder is hypertrophied and shows diverticula with vesicoureteral reflux Treatment: Catheterization: drains urine and decompress bladder and upper urinary tracts Endoscopic ablation of valves (definitive treatment)

questions.text: What is the condition seen here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal Varices The endoscopic image shows esophageal varices

Highyeild:

Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal distal esophageal veins connecting the portal and systemic circulations . They form due to portal hypertension, which commonly is a result of cirrhosis, resistance to portal blood flow, and increased portal venous blood inflow. Normal portal pressure is between 5-10 mmHg but in the presence of portal obstruction, the pressure may be as high as 15-20 mmHg Management of Active bleeding: Intravenous (IV) access, hemodynamic resuscitation Overtransfusion increases portal pressure and increases rebleeding risk Treat coagulopathy as necessary. Fresh frozen plasma may increase blood volume and increase rebleeding risk Monitor mental status. Avoid sedation, nephrotoxic drugs, and beta - blockers acutely. IV octreotide to lower portal venous pressure as adjuvant to endoscopic management. IV bolus of 50 micrograms followed by a drip of 50 micrograms/hr. Terlipressin (alternative): 2 mg q4h IV for 24 to 48 hours, then 1 mg q4h Erythromycin 250 mg IV 30 to 120 minutes before endoscopy. Urgent upper GI endoscopy for diagnosis and treatment If no contraindication, start beta-blocker (nitrates are an alternative) Variceal band ligation is preferred to sclerotherapy for bleeding varices and for non-bleeding medium-to-large varices to decrease bleeding risk. Prevent recurrence of acute bleeding: Vasoconstrictors: terlipressin, octreotide (reduce portal pressure) Endoscopic band ligation (EBL) : if bleeding recurs/portal pressure measurement shows portal pressure remains greater than 12 mmHg TIPS : Second-line therapy if the above methods fail.

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Gastric ulcer- discrete mucosal lesion with a punched-out smooth ulcer base. The everted margins are suggestive of malignant ulcer. Most gastric ulcers tend to occur at the junction of the body and antrum, along the lesser curvature. Option: C. Candida is normally found in the throat but can become pathogenic and produce esophagitis in a compromised host. Endoscopy with biopsy is the most useful for diagnosis. Candida has a characteristic appearance of white plaques or exudate with friability. Treatment: oral fluconazole 400 mg on first day followed by 200 mg daily for 14 to 21 days. Option: D. Barrett’s oesophagus is a metaplastic change in the lining mucosa of the oesophagus in response to chronic gastro-oesophageal Reflux. The hallmark of ‘specialised’ Barrett’s epithelium is the presence of mucus-secreting goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia)

questions.text: A patient with a history of umbilical swelling, initially asymptomatic for many years, now complains of pain over the swelling. The swelling was reducible initially but is now non-reducible. What is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:

Umbilectomy with herniorrhaphy The patient presents with umbilical hernia with features of obstruction and in this patient, umbilectomy ( excision of umbilical cicatrix) is done and herniorrhaphy

Umbilical hernias are commonly seen in overweight men with a thinned and attenuated midline raphe or in postpartum women with a weakened abdominal wall bulge creates crescent shaped appearance to the umbilicus Small hernias contain extraperitoneal fat or omentum while large hernias contain small or large bowel Clinical features Pain due to tension Symptoms of intestinal bowel obstruction Overlying skin irritation and ulceration Spontaneous rupture is rare Treatment Indications of surgery are persistence after age of two years, defect is more than 2 cm in size, acquired/adult umbilical hernia Surgeries can be primary closure of defect , Mayo repair, Sublay mesh repair, umbilectomy

questions.text: What is the treatment plan for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Split thickness skin grafting The mainstay of burn wound repair has been split skin autograft

Highyeild:

Split thickness skin graft, also called as Thiersch graft, is removal of full epidermis with part of dermis from donor area Indications: Well granulated ulcer Clean wound or defect which cannot be apposed After surgery to cover and close defect created ( eg., after wide excision in malignancy , after mastectomy ) Prerequisite: Healthy granulation area Beta hemolytic streptococci load less than 10 power 5 , per gram of tissue , otherwise graft failure will occur DISADVANTAGES Contracture Primary contracture ( thicker the graft more the primary contracture) Secondary contracture ( thinner the graft more the secondary contracture) Seroma and hematoma formation Infection, graft failure Loss of hair growth, blunting sensation Dry, scaling of skin due to non functioning of sebaceous glands

questions.text: A patient with oral cancer underwent radical surgery and PMMC flap reconstruction as shown. What is the most important indicator for considering adjuvant radiotherapy in this patient?

Preferred approach for treatment of oral cavity carcinoma is surgical resection with adequate (1cm) surgical margins with management of regional nodal basin They metastasize to submandibular, submental and upper cervical nodes and are almost always treated with supraomohyoid neck dissection at time of primary resection with few rare exceptions ( T1 oral tongue lesions that have less than 4 mm depth of invasion) Adjuvant radiotherapy 1 major criterion ( extranodal extension and/or involved margin [<1mm]) or 2 minor criteria ( close margin [1-4.9 mm], multiple involved nodes, largest node >3 cm, lymphovascular invasion/perineural invasion, T3/T4 Adjuvant chemotherapy is reserved for those with positive margins or extracapsular invasions

questions.text: Identify the ulcer shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Venous ulcer Venous leg ulcers characteristically develop in the skin of the gaiter region, the area between the muscles of the calf and the ankle A venous ulcer usually has a gently sloping edge and the floor contains granulation tissue covered by a variable amount of slough and exudate

Highyeild:

Causes of leg ulceration Venous disease: superficial incompetence , deep incompetence or obstruction Arterial ischemic ulcers Vasculitic ulcers Neoplastic ulcers Traumatic ulcers Neuropathic ulcers Infections Symptoms in patients with varicose veins or venous insufficiency, when they occur, include a dull ache, throbbing or heaviness, or pressure sensation in the legs typically after prolonged standing These symptoms usually are relieved with leg elevation. Additional symptoms may include cramping, burning, pruritus, leg swelling, and skin ulceration. Edema, stasis dermatitis, and skin ulceration near the ankle may be present if there is superficial venous insufficiency and venous hypertension. Findings of deep venous insufficiency include increased leg circumference, venous varicosities, edema, and skin changes. The edema, which is usually pitting, may be confined to the ankles, extend above the ankles to the knees, or involve the thighs in severe cases. Over time, the edema may become less pitting and more indurated. Investigations: Duplex scans Done to assess the status of deep and superficial veins Presence of reflux does not confirm venous ulcer but support the diagnosis in absence of another cause and helps direct treatment Biopsy Indicated if malignancy is suspected Management: Superficial venous ablation therapy Compression Pentoxifylline , which increase microvascular perfusion buy decreasing plasm cellular viscosity and cytokine inhibition Biological dressings ( including fetal keratinocytes and collagen meshes ) Punch grafts and ulcer excision with mesh grafting Greatest risk of re-ulceration is in post thrombotic leg

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with recurrent diarrhea, abdominal pain and foul smelling stool. Colonoscopy image of the patient is shown below. What is the diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudomembranous colitis The given history along with colonoscopy image points towards diagnosis of pseudomembranous colitis

Highyeild:

Pseudomembranous colitis is an inflammatory condition of the colon primarily caused by Clostridium difficile infection. Pathogenesis: Usually results from the overgrowth of Clostridium difficile, often triggered by antibiotic use, which disrupts the normal gut microbiota. difficile produces toxins, particularly toxin A and toxin B, which damage the colon's mucosal lining. Clinical Presentation: Watery diarrhea, often foul-smelling. Abdominal pain and cramping. Pseudomembranes (yellow-white plaques) visible on colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy. Risk Factors: Antibiotic use, especially broad-spectrum antibiotics. Recent hospitalization or healthcare exposure. Advanced age. Immunocompromised patients. Diagnosis Stool tests to detect C. difficile toxins, such as toxin A and toxin B. Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy to visualize pseudomembranes. Treatment : Discontinuation of the inciting antibiotics if possible. Antibiotic therapy: First-line: Oral vancomycin or oral fidaxomicin for severe cases. Second-line: Oral metronidazole for mild to moderate cases. Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) in recurrent or refractory cases.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Familial adenomatous polyposis is defined by presence of more than 100 colorectal adenomas but is also characterised by duodenal adenomas and multiple extraintestinal manifestations. Lifetime risk of colorectal cancer is up to 100% in those with APC mutations Option: C. Acute gastritis is temporary stomach lining inflammation caused by stress on the gastric mucosa, manifesting as either hemorrhagic or non-hemorrhagic symptoms. This condition can develop due to various factors, including uremia, ischemia, shock, corrosive agents, medications, radiation, trauma, severe burns, sepsis, or alkaline-bile reflux Option: D . Among the common endoscopic features of UC seen within the colon are edema, erythema, mucosal friability and bleeding, erosions and ulcerations, and loss of the typical vascular pattern

questions.text: A newborn baby presented with a difficulty in breathing. Auscultation of the chest revealed gurgling sounds and heart sounds shifted to the right. The chest radiograph confirmed a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Which among the following is the most common location for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left posterolateral Most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is left posterolateral ( Bochdalek hernia )

Highyeild:

Diaphragmatic hernia is the herniation of abdominal content through diaphragm into the chest Congenital diaphragmatic hernias are associated with lung hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension, cardiac defects and gastroesophageal reflux, with half having additional anomalies. Commonly, there is a left posterolateral or Bochdalek defect , less commonly a ventral or Morgagni defect The diagnosis is usually made antenatally . A prognosis based on an observed-to-expected lung–head ratio (ultrasound), total fetal lung volume (magnetic resonance imaging) Management After birth - intubation, muscle relaxation and gentle ventilation aim to maintain pH, and oxygen saturation so avoiding right-to-left shunting Repair is offered if pulmonary circulation stabilises. The defect can be approached from abdomen or chest, either open or minimally invasive ( small defect may need few sutures, whereas large ones need a conical Silastic or GOR-TEX patch) Urgent reduction of bowel does not improve gas exchange

Table:

questions.text: A male child experienced acute scrotal pain while playing. He was taken to the emergency department and a USG doppler was performed, followed by immediate surgical exploration. The following finding was seen. What is the probable diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Torsion of testicular appendage with Gangrene

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Testicular torsion with Gangrene The given image shows testicular torsion with gangrene . Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency

Highyeild:

Testicular torsion is the twisting of a spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised . Clinical features Common between 10 and 25 years of age Sudden severe pain in groin and lower abdomen Nausea and vomiting Scrotum is swollen and tender Tender twisted cord can be palpated Cremasteric reflex is lost Doppler ultrasound confirms diagnosis ( absence of blood supply to affected testis) Management In case of doubt in diagnosis, urgent scrotal exploration to be done Window of opportunity for surgical intervention and testicular salvage is 6 hours from onset of pain If testis is viable when untwisted, it is prevented from twisting again by fixation with non absorbable sutures and the other testis should also be fixed In case of clinical doubt of viability , it should be wrapped in a warm swab and observed for a few minutes. If small incision in tunica albuginea demonstrates bright red arterial bleeding - testis may survive In case of infarcted testis , it should be removed and patient counselled about prosthetic replacement

questions.text: A 76 year old elderly man presents with confusion. He is on antihypertensive medication, and on aspirin after a recent MI. He recalls a trivial fall from a chair 3 weeks ago. Other neurological examination was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subdural hemorrhage The given history along with NCCT showing hypodense lesion on left side, points towards diagnosis of chronic subdural hematoma

Highyeild:

Chronic subdural hematoma is a common cause of acute neurological deterioration in older adults There is usually a history of recent injury and the resulting hematoma can expand over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately producing symptoms of raised ICP or focal deficits. Especially in context of antiplatelet or anticoagulant medication, even apparently trivial impacts may be responsible ( in acute deterioration - anticoagulation should be reversed, by Vitamin K or transfusion of recombinant clotting factors) Imaging reveals hypodensity over brain surface Recent bleeding - isodense or hyperdense Acute on chronic subdural - mixed density Management Small bleeds without symptoms or only headache: corticosteroids Burr hole is done in majority and urgency is dictated by clinical condition of patient and imaging of mass effect

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Epidural hemorrhage is due to h ematoma between inner table of skull and outer periosteal layer of dura and are commonly seen after trauma or surgery. These are usually arterial ( middle meningeal artery ) and appear as hyperdense hematoma on unenhanced CT . It is limited by sutures but can cross dural folds of falx and tentorium Option: B. Subarachnoid hemorrhages are life-threatening and result from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid and pia mater. The characteristic presenting symptom is the thunderclap headache , which patients may describe as the “worst headache of my life.”

Highyeild:

Carcinoma penis is most typically a squamous cell carcinoma arising in skin of glans penis or prepuce, which may be flat and infiltrating or warty in appearance Grading T1: confined to skin T2: invading corpus spongiosum or corpus cavernosum T3: invading urethra T4: invading adjacent structured The earliest lymph node to spread is inguinal node (N1 and N2) and to iliac (N3) Distant metastasis are infrequent Treatment of lesion Surgical excision is the mainstay of treatment for most primary tumors, with 2 cm margin of normal tissue be removed small lesions , low grade and low stage: organ preserving surgery, such as Mohs surgery Tumors affecting glans penis require glansectomy , with more advanced tumors requiring partial penectomy Advanced cases: Total penectomy with formation of perineal urethrostomy Treatment of lymph nodes Delayed for at least 3 weeks after local treatment of primary lesion in enlarged lymph nodes ( if caused by infection, they would subside with antibiotics) Palpable nodes: ultrasound guided fine needle aspiration confirms diagnosis and block dissection of both groins done Non palpable nodes: Sentinel lymph node biopsy done followed by inguinal node dissection if SLNB is positive

questions.text: Identify the given drain:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Closed Suction drain The given image is Romovac suction drain (closed suction drain) Suction is created by pressing the suction corrugation The sharp metallic inducer is used to pass the tube into required area after puncturing the skin Uses : thyroidectomy , mastectomy, radical dissection, wide excisions, flap surgeries etc.,

Highyeild:

CLASSIFICATION OF DRAINS: Open (static) drain: Aid in passive drainage of cavity based on gravity by forming a channel between body and environment Example: corrugated drain, penrose drain. Infection rate is higher. Closed siphon drain: Drain is connected to a sterile bag with or without a one-way valve. It reduces the infection. Closed suction drain: Negative pressure of -100 to 500 mmHg is used to create a vacuum to drain the secretions. Sump suction drain: Negative suction with a parallel air-vent is used to prevent the adjacent soft tissues being sucked into the lumen of the drain. Under water seal drain to drain pleural space

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with acute retention of urine which is drained via the suprapubic route. A retrograde urethrogram was done and is as shown below. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: B
options.text: Urethral repair with graft from buccal mucosa

questions.correct_answer: B. Urethral repair with graft from buccal mucosa
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urethral repair with graft from buccal mucosa Retrograde urethrogram stricture of bulbar urethra . Urethral repair is done in these cases and buccal mucosal graft is used ( most common tissue substitute )

Highyeild:

A urethral stricture is an area of scarring or fibrosis that causes concentric narrowing of urethra, impeding flow of urine as it drains from bladder Causes include, trauma, iatrogenic (33%), inflammatory and idiopathic(33%) Symptoms include, incomplete emptying, weak urinary stream , urinary urgency /frequency and pain It can occur at any segment of urethra, but is most common in bulbar urethra Ascending urethrogram is essential to see site, type, extent and false passage Treatment can be either via endoscopic or surgical reconstruction Endoscopic treatment includes urethral dilatation or stricture excision with cystoscope ( direct vision internal urethrotomy). Common practice is to attempt one endoscopic intervention prior to referral for reconstructive surgery Urethroplasty can be Anastomotic urethroplasty - bulbar urethral traumatic strictures where there is gap in urethra ( dissection of two ends of urethra, spatulation and anastomosis ) Augmentation urethroplasty - non traumatic and long strictures (structured segment of urethra is incised and augmented with patch. Usual choice of patch is buccal mucosa. If required, lingual grafts can be harvested from the undersurface of the tongue. Techniques: dorsal onlay augmentation, dorsal inlay or ventral onlay)

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for a leg ulcer due to burns. What is the mechanism by which a graft receives its nutritional supply on postoperative day 3?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inosculation Inosculation occurs during the third day of graft placement, in which graft and host vessels from anastomoses

Highyeild:

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases Plasmatic circulation ( serum imbibition) During the first 48 hours nourishes the graft with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries Revascularisation Starts after 48 hours with two phases Primary is neovascularization in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into graft, and secondary is inosculation in which graft and host vessels from anastomoses Organisation begins immediately after grafting with fibrin later at graft-bed interface, holding graft in place This is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts Grafts are securely adherent to beds by 10 -14 days Sensibility returns to graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 - 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months ( pain returns first with light touch and temperature returning later) Most common cause of graft failure is hematoma under graft

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Stanford type B aortic dissection. What is the most appropriate initial management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer beta blocker and intensive blood pressure monitoring

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer beta blocker and intensive blood pressure monitoring
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administer beta blocker and intensive blood pressure monitoring Stanford Type B aortic dissection are best managed with antihypertensive drugs and intensive blood pressure monitoring Intervention is indicated in complicated cases ( pain increases or fails to resolve, dissection is associated with evidence of malperfusion) Intervention of choice in complicated cases: Percutaneously placed endovascular stents

Highyeild:

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of aorta , resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues , splitting medial layer and creating false lumen It most commonly occurs in ascending aorta and is most common in men typically in age group of 50 to 70 years Predisposing factors include , age , hypertension ,Marfan syndrome , pregnancy , coarctation of aorta , Turner or Noonan syndromes , iatrogenic Clinical features Tearing interscapular pain Based on extent of arterial dissection Renal pain and renal failure ( renal arteries ) Abdominal pain and bowel ischemia ( mesenteric arteries ) Paraplegia ( spinal arteries ) Leg pain, pallor , loss of or reduced pulses , acute limb ischemia ( iliac arteries ) Investigations CT - gold standard Management Type A - usually require surgical intervention Type B- blood pressure control is done and if complication, surgery is done ( percutaneously placed endovascular stents is the standard intervention of choice )

questions.text: A patient presented with dysuria and increased frequency of micturition. He has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. The radiographic image is given below. Identify the calculi shown:

Calcium Phosphate The given history along with radiography, points towards calcium phosphate stone

Highyeild:

Phosphate stones are either calcium phosphate or calcium , magnesium, ammonium phosphate stone usually occurring in an infected urine . It is smooth and white in colour In an alkaline urine, it enlarges rapidly, filling renal calyces taking their shape ( staghorn calculus ) It is radiopaque and attains larger size
